RE: License#: CB820201177
Dear Ms. Moffett:
Attached is the Renewal Inspection Report for the above referenced agency completed
on 12/27/2024. A Preliminary exit conference was held with your agency on 1/9/2025.
Due to the violations of applicable licensing rules, a written corrective action plan is
required. The corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of this letter and must
include the following:
• For any repeat violations, why the prior corrective action plan did not result
in compliance.
• How compliance with each citation will be achieved.
• Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action plan.
• Specific time frames for each citation as to when the correction will be
completed or implemented.
• How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
• The signature of the responsible party and a date.
Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available, and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact the area manager Jessica VandenHeuvel at 616-204-6992.
P.O. BOX 30650 • LANSING, MICHIGAN 48909
www.michigan.gov • (517) 335-1980

Sincerely,

III. DESCRIPTION OF FINDINGS
The facility is in compliance with all applicable licensing statutes and rules except for
the following:
CPA Rule 400.12212 Personnel records.
(2) The personnel record must contain all the following
information before employment may occur:
(e) A record of any convictions other than minor traffic
violations from either of the following:
(ii) An entity accessing either Michigan state police
records or equivalent state or Canadian provincial law
enforcement agency where the person usually resides.
One of two new employee records reviewed showed the employee's ICHAT
completed 1/29/2024 was after the employee’s 11/13/2023 date of hire.
Repeat Violation Established:
Renewal 2023, CAP Approved 8/8/2023.
CPA Rule 400.12212 Personnel records.
(3) The personnel record must contain both of the
following:
(a) A written evaluation of a staff member's
performance within a probationary period or not later
than 6 months after the staff member assumes his or

her current responsibilities. After the initial evaluation, a
written evaluation must be conducted every 12 months.
One of seven employee records reviewed showed the employee's probationary
evaluation due by 5/13/2024 was completed late on 5/29/2024.
CPA Rule 400.12405 Change of placement.
(3) The agency shall document all the following in the
child's record before a change of placement occurs:
(e) Replacement preparation of all relevant parties,
including the child or infant, which includes an
explanation as to why the change is necessary.
Two of six open foster child records reviewed did not show documentation of
subsection (e) as required by the rule related to one child's replacement on
4/26/2024 and another child's replacements on 4/6/2024 and 7/3/2024.
CPA Rule 400.12413 Medical and dental care policy.
(1) An agency's medical and dental care policy must,
include all the following:
(c) A physical examination for each child as follows,
unless a greater frequency is medically indicated:
(i) A comprehensive medical examination, including a
behavioral/mental health and trauma screening, within
30 calendar days from the date the child entered into
an out-of-home placement, regardless of the date of
the last physical examination.
One of six open foster child records reviewed showed the child's mental health
screening due by 3/6/2024 was completed late on 3/26/2024.
CPA Rule 400.12413 Medical and dental care policy.
(1) An agency's medical and dental care policy must,
include all the following:
(d) Current immunizations for each child as required by
section 5111 of the public health code, 1978 PA 368,
MCL 333.5111. All the following apply:

(iii) If documentation of immunization or a copy of the
waiver is unavailable, then immunizations must begin
within 30 calendar days of placement.
One of six foster child records reviewed showed the child’s Hepatitis A
immunization expired 7/29/2024.
CPA Rule 400.12413 Medical and dental care policy.
(1) An agency's medical and dental care policy must,
include all the following:
(f) A dental re-examination must be obtained at least
every 9 months, unless a greater frequency is
indicated.
Three of six open foster child records reviewed did not show compliance:
• A first and second record did not show documentation of the child's dental
exam due by 11/5/2024 and 11/16/2024 respectively.
• A third record showed the child's dental exam due by 7/5/2024 was
completed late on 7/17/2024.
CPA Rule 400.12415 Unusual incident reporting policy.
(1) An agency must adhere to the following incident
reporting protocols:
(a) Immediately notify the child's parents; the
department licensing authority; the lawyer guardian ad
litem and court, as applicable; the department; and the
foster child's parents, if any of the following occurs:
(iv) Any medical and mental illness or condition that
results in treatment at a hospital emergency room or
inpatient hospitalization of a foster child.
During the course of the file review it was discovered that the agency had a child
who had attempted self-harm on 8/26/2024 by taking 4 Tylenol pills. The agency
notified the referral source but Division of child Welfare Licensing(DCWL).
CPA Rule 400.12418 Development of service plans.
(2) An agency shall complete written service plans for
each child and parent or parents, as follows:
(a) Within 30 calendar days from removal from the
home.

One of six open foster child records reviewed showed the child’s 2/8/2024-
3/8/2024 initial service plan (ISP) was completed two days late on 3/11/2024.
Repeat Violation Established:
Renewal 2023- CAP approved 8/8/2024.
CPA Rule 400.12417 Foster parent information.
(1) An agency shall provide a foster parent with all the
following information before the placement or
replacement of a child:
(c) Available known information about the child's
health.
One of six open foster child records reviewed did not show documentation of
subsection (c) related to the child's replacement on 1/26/2024 and 4/8/2024.
CPA Rule 400.12417 Foster parent information.
(1) An agency shall provide a foster parent with all the
following information before the placement or
replacement of a child:
(d) Any known history of abuse or neglect of the child.
One of six open foster child records reviewed did not show documentation of
subsection (d) related to the child's replacement on 1/26/2024 and 4/8/2024.
CPA Rule 400.12417 Foster parent information.
(1) An agency shall provide a foster parent with all the
following information before the placement or
replacement of a child:
(e) All known emotional and psychological factors
relating to the care of the child.
One of six open foster child records reviewed did not show documentation of
subsection (e) related to the child's replacement on 1/26/2024 and 4/8/2024.
CPA Rule 400.12417 Foster parent information.
(1) An agency shall provide a foster parent with all the
following information before the placement or
replacement of a child:

(f) All known behaviors of the child.
One of six open foster child records reviewed did not show documentation of
subsection (f) related to the child's replacement on 1/26/2024 and 4/8/2024.
CPA Rule 400.12418 Development of service plans.
(2) An agency shall complete written service plans for
each child and parent or parents, as follows:
(b) Within 120 calendar days after the initial removal
and at least once every 90 calendar days thereafter.
Five of six open foster child records reviewed did not show compliance:
• One child's 2/16/2024- 5/15/2025 updated service plan(USP) was
completed 7 days late on 5/3/2024; and the child's 5/16/2024-8/13/2024
USP was completed 15 days late on 8/29/2024.
• A second child's 2/29/2024-5/28/2024 USP was completed 12 days late on
6/10/2024. This child's 5/29/2024-8/25/2024 USP was completed 2 days
late on 8/29/2025.
• A third child's 5/29/2024-8/26/2024 USP was completed 1 day on
8/28/2024.
• A fourth child's 3/9/2024-6/7/2024 USP was completed 19 days late on
6/26/2024.
• A fifth child's 5/21/2024-8/18/2024 USP was completed 9 days late on
8/28/2024.
Repeat Violation Established:
Renewal 2023 CAP approved 8/8/2023.
CPA Rule 400.12418 Development of service plans.
(5) An agency shall involve the child's parent or parents
and the foster parents in the development of service
plans to enable the parent or parents and foster
parents to understand the plan for the child and the
parents' and the foster parent's role in assisting the
agency in carrying out the plan. An agency shall give a
copy to and review the parent-agency treatment plan
with the parent or parents and foster parents. The
agency must inform the parent or parents and foster
parent that the information in the parent-agency
treatment plan and any other information about the
child and the child's family is confidential.
Three of six open foster child records reviewed did not show compliance:

• One child's record indicated the child's ISP treatment plan was
“mailed/texted" pertaining to the birth mother, but the treatment plan was
not dated and I could not discern if that action occurred timely with regard
to signature time requirements. This child's 2/16/2024-5/15/2024 and
8/14/2024-11/11/2024 treatment plan was not signed by the birth mother.
• A second child's 2/29/2024-5/28/2024 USP treatment plan was not signed
by the caregiver until 8/20/2024.
• A third child's 1/30/2024- 2/28/2024 ISP treatment plan and the child’s next
two USP treatment plans were not signed by the birth mother.
Repeat Violation Established:
Renewal 2023, CAP approved 8/8/2024; cited under FOM 722-8 D.
CPA Rule 400.12324 Reevaluation.
(2) The annual reevaluation must include a
determination and assessment of all the following:
(b) Family functioning and interrelationships as
determined by observation of, and interviews with,
each member of the household and each social service
worker who has had children placed in the home during
the last licensing period.
Two of four open foster home records reviewed did not show documentation of
the foster parent’s individual strengths and weaknesses as reported by the foster
parents. One of these two records also did not show documentation of
observation of the child in the home.
CPA Rule 400.12324 Reevaluation.
(8) An agency shall complete a reevaluation and make
a licensing recommendation to the department at least
15 calendar days before the expiration date of the
foster home license.
Two of four open foster home records reviewed showed the recommendation to
the department was not within 15 days of the foster home's 4/19/2024 and
7/13/2024 respective licensing expiration date. The former record showed
submission on 12/17/2024 and the latter on 7/23/2024.
CPA Rule 400.12604 Orientation.

(1) An agency shall provide an orientation for
prospective applicants for adoption before an adoptive
application is provided.
One of one approved adoptive applicant records reviewed showed the applicant
was provided an application prior to an orientation.
CPA Rule 400.12605 Adoptive family evaluation.
(1) An agency social service worker shall complete a
written adoptive evaluation within 90 days of the family
signing an adoption application and prior to approving a
family for adoption.
One of one approved adoptive applicant records reviewed showed the family’s
adoptive evaluation was not completed within 90 days of the family’s 2/9/2024
application date.

VI. EVALUATION OF RENEWAL PERIOD
There were no substantiated incidents of maltreatment in care during this licensing
period.

There were no incidents of substantiated corporal punishment during this licensing
period.
Corrective Action Plan Compliance
The agency has submitted one acceptable corrective action plans during this
licensing period. This corrective action plan related to the agency’s 2023 renewal
inspection, where the agency received 25 citations of which 12 were repeat
violations from the prior two years. This 2025 renewal inspection the agency
received 18 rule violations, of which 4 are repeat violations from the last renewal
inspection. The agency’s corrective action plan compliance around these 4 rule
violations is as follows: the number of individual cases cited for R400.12212(2)(e)
and R400.12418(2)(a) have decreased. With respect to the other two repeat
violations R400.12418(2)(b) and R400.12418(5) the number of individual cases
cited increased.
As it relates to the action steps in the 2023 corrective action plan, the agency has
implemented, completed or initiated the majority of action steps indicated in the
corrective action plan with respect to personnel, licensing, foster care, and
adoption. As it relates to the agency’s financial stability violation, the agency has
completed the action steps related to that citation, but it continues to have financial
stability concerns. The agency reports it continues to work on this area.
It is noteworthy the agency’s financial issues brought forth another special
investigation related to financial instability in November 2024. This special
investigation, 2025SIC0000151 stemmed from a financial memo to DCWL with
respect to the agency 2023 independent financial audit and an ongoing concern
noted within that financial document. The 2025SIC0000151 special investigation
report found the agency continues to have financial liabilities, with large debts in
some specific areas. The evidence also showed that the agency is managing
these debts and paying its debtors timely. Only through additional time, and with
increased revenue may it be proven that agency’s financial progress will or will not
continue.
Chief Administrator Assessment
The agency submitted a chief administrator’s report dated 12/20/2024. This report
indicated information as to how the agency’s second provisional license came to
be; and its connection to the agency’ 2022 special investigation that brought on
the first provisional license due to allegations of financial instability. The chief
administrator reported verbally and within this report that financially since its
liabilities have exceeded its assets the agency will continue to operate as a going
concern until all its debts are satisfied. The chief administrator reported it is
working on these debts. She further reported all its bills are current and its
average bank balance is $90,000 with a current balance of $132,100. The chief
administrator indicated in this report that the agency is planning to absolve past
liabilities through crowd funding. The chief administrator expressed concern that
being on provisional licenses and being investigated related to the agency’s
finances when it has been able to continue to operate and pay its bills, has

impacted staff morale as well as foster parent and adoptive parent retentions and
approvals.
The agency indicated with respect to other areas cited during the past renewal
inspection that the agency has not had any borrowed beds placement since the
last inspection and the agency continues to do the work on compliance in all areas
by way of task checklists, in service training, monthly supervision agendas, and
email reminders to employees related to various tasks and due dates.
Financial Overview
I received and reviewed a copy of the 2024 annual operating financial budget, and
an end of the year 12/31/2023 independent financial audit report. The agency was
on a 1st and 2nd provisional license for financial concerns, but over the past several
months they appear to be moving in a positive direction, they have set up payment
plans and are paying down debts.
Staff Interviews
In addition to a discussion with the chief administrator, as well as, the licensee
designee, who serves as the licensing/adoption supervisor, I interviewed two
foster care workers, an adoption worker, licensing worker, and the foster care
supervisor. The employees interviewed reported feeling appreciated and
supported, that the administrators have maintained an open-door policy, that there
is good agency communication, and the work environment is family oriented and
welcoming. Some areas these employees viewed as areas for growth included
upgrading the agency’s technology, having more than one person trained/being
responsible for a major agency task/a significant agency function, more
advertising and involvement with other entities to establish a community presence
and recruit families, and more funding so as to allow the agency to do more for
children and families.
Description of Agency Walk Through
A walk through of the facility did not indicate any concerns or safety issues. The
agency has space and equipment for its staff; and files were properly stored.
VII. FIELD ANALYST FINDINGS
There were two identified safety alerts.
Safety Alert 1: An unlicensed relative caregiver’s home did not have an operable
smoke detector on each level of occupancy and/or near all sleeping areas. Also,
there was no operable carbon monoxide detector in the home.
Resolution: The agency made contact with the relative caregiver on 12/20/2024 and
purchased a smoke detector and carbon monoxide detector for the home. The
foster care worker went back to the family’s home on 1/6/2025 and verified that the
smoke/carbon monoxide detector was installed.

Safety Alert 2: A foster home’s smoke detector on the second level of the home
between the sleeping areas is beeping.
Resolution: The agency reported it contacted the family about changing the battery
in the smoke detector on 1/14/2025; and it opened a special evaluation on the foster
home. The agency reported that the family indicated the smoke detectors are hard
wired and all batteries needed to be replaced at the same time. The agency reported
the family had an electrician come out; and a licensing worker verified installation of
a functional smoke detector on 1/22/2025.
VIII. RECOMMENDATION
Upon receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan, the issuance of a regular
license is recommended.
